body:
It is a known issue that `PSCredential` is not working (yet) for OpenSSH remoting, see [here](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/866b558771a20cca3daa47f300e830b31a24ee95/docs/new-features/remoting-over-ssh/README.md):

> You can currently establish a connection either interactively with user name and password or via key authentication. PSCredential is not yet supported.

You have also used the wrong parameter set, `-ComputerName` is at the moment only for classic WinRm remoting (i.e. Windows to Windows), you need to use the `-HostName` parameter for cross platform OpenSSH remoting (which needs some setup beforehand, see my link for instructions to do so).
Given the fact that this feature gap is known and the cmdlet was not used correctly, I think we can close this issue.

Now I get this

PS /root> Invoke-command -hostname tgcs011 {get-process} -Credential our\administrator

PowerShell credential request
Enter your credentials.
Password for user our\administrator: ********

Invoke-Command : Parameter set cannot be resolved using the specified named parameters. One or more parameters issued cannot be used together or an insufficient number of parameters were provided.
At line:1 char:1
+ Invoke-command -hostname tgcs011 {get-process} -Credential our\admini ...
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [Invoke-Command], ParameterBindingException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : AmbiguousParameterSet,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.InvokeCommandCommand

Thoughts
Please re-read my comment above. PSCredential is not supported at the moment, you need to setup RSA key based authentication.
Are you talking about using SSH?  if so none of my Windows servers run SSHD
Read the link in my first answer. Without OpenSsh, there is no cross-platform remoting

I just downloaded openssh-win64 will test using SSH 

Thanks

Guys  got further along

Added -Authentication basic to the command

PS /root> Invoke-command -computername tgcs011 {get-process} -Credential "our\administrator" -Authentication basic

Again, the -ComputerName and -Credential parameters are not to be used for cross platform remoting at the moment. Read the OpenSsh link in my first answer on how to setup and use OpenSsh remoting.

OpenSSH was installed on my Windows 2012 R2 server and did not work the SSHD service fails to start I posted in the OpenSSH forum waiting for a response.
When they going to support -computername   I watched a video on this and they claim a script you write in windows will work on Linux this is not true if this does not work

Ok now I have openssh working on a Windows 2012 R2 server. 

I can ssh into my Windows 2012 r2 server from my Cent OS server

Now back to powershell commands
tried these two  both failed

PS /root> Invoke-Command -HostName 10.2.8.32 -username administrator [get-process]
Invoke-Command : A positional parameter cannot be found that accepts argument '[get-process]'.
At line:1 char:1
+ Invoke-Command -HostName 10.2.8.32 -username administrator [get-proce ...
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : InvalidArgument: (:) [Invoke-Command], ParameterBindingException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : PositionalParameterNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.InvokeCommandCommand

PS /root> Enter-PSSession -HostName 10.2.8.32 -UserName administrator
administrator@10.2.8.32's password:
administrator@10.2.8.32's password: Enter-PSSession : The background process reported an error with the following message: The SSH client session has ended with error message: Permission denied, please try again..
At line:1 char:1
+ Enter-PSSession -HostName 10.2.8.32 -UserName administrator
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : ResourceUnavailable: (:) [Enter-PSSession], PSRemotingTransportException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.Management.Automation.Remoting.PSRemotingDataStructureException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.EnterPSSessionCommand

The syntax of the first command is incorrect and the error message is telling you exactly that. It should be
````powershell
Invoke-Command -HostName '10.2.8.32' -username administrator -ScriptBlock {get-process}
````
The error message from the 2nd command suggests either a real permission problem in your network or an incorrect setup of PowerShell together with OpenSsh.
I currently have a pending blog post on the 'Hey Scripting guy' site about this topic. I'll publish it in the meantime on my private blog today to help you out so hold on tight.
Thanks and Merry Christmas

Ok, @trgrassijr55  my blog post can be found [here](https://bracketsandbraces.blogspot.co.at/2017/12/powershell-core-cross-platform-remoting.html), the section `Configuring PowerShell remoting` will be especially of interest to you. It shows Windows to Linux remoting as an example but the reverse case is actually easier. The SSH tools are slightly different on Windows and on Linx so bear that in mind. Make sure you replace the string `beta.9` with `rc.2` or whatever version of PowerShell Core you use. Merry Xmas as well!

I have OpenSSH installed now 
I can SSH from my CEntOS server to my Windows 2012 R2 server get a CMD window and can enter commands no problem

But still can not get the powershell working.

Any ideas?

My only guess is that it must be something to do with how you configured the PowerShell  subsystem in OpenSsh or security/file permissions in your environment. Sorry, but without seeing the config files it's hard to guess for me since I haven't developed it but only used it.
Since I expect it to work, maybe trying to get remoting from Windows to Linux working first might be an idea as well since you can then just copy-paste the commands from my blog...

From Openssh sshd_config file

# override default of no subsystems
Subsystem	sftp	sftp-server.exe
Subsystem powershell C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe -sshs -NoLogo -NoProfile

what security/file permissions ?????

There's a slight complexity here.  Setting up OpenSSH  in Windows there a conflict on services been install on newer Windows Insider Builds having the following services previously installed: SSH Broker and SSH Proxy. 

If you manage to install Windows OpenSSH from Chocolatey, it will installed services: sshd and ssh-agent.  The you need to create the firewall rule for port 22.

Also, in Windows, you need to use the following subsystem to use PowerShell Core:
```
Subsystem 	powershell	C:/Program Files/PowerShell/6.0.0-rc.2/pwsh.exe -sshs -NoLogo -NoProfile
```
As you can see, every time there's an updated PowerShell Core version, you will need to change this path   ("C:/Program Files/PowerShell/6.0.0-rc.2/") manually and restart all SSH services installed in Windows.

By the way, you could use WSMAN for connect Linux to Windows but I still consider is a tedious installation on the Linux side.  

I have documented these steps in an old blog which still works:
http://www.maxtblog.com/2016/12/powershell-open-source-windows-psremoting-to-linux-with-openssh/ 

I'm currently working in an updated version which I hope to post in a few hours. I will post the updated link when I'm done.

I changed the sub system to your posted entry but it failed also.

see debug 3 log from openssh

[debug3.txt](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/1587865/debug3.txt)

That path does not exist
C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell is the only folder named under program files.

Am I missing something on the Windows server?

The path is incorrect 

I have port 22 open because I can SSH to the Windows server no problem
Just having issues with remote powershell working

I would love to have WSMAN working that is like WINRM correct?

@trgrassijr55 The subsystem on the Windows server should point to pwsh.exe not powershell.exe (it could work but let's keep it simpler for now)
Also don't forget to enable RSAAuthentication, PubkeyAuthentication and PasswordAuthentication in sshd_config (and restart the service afterwards)

Also don't forget to enable RSAAuthentication, PubkeyAuthentication and PasswordAuthentication

Sorry but that path does not exist 
pwsh.exe is not on this windows server 

what is wrong here?

I got it working.
I had to install powershell 6.0.0-rc.2 on my Windows 2012 R2 server now I can enter-PSSession and invoke-command are working via openssh 

Now to see if I can get -computername  to work

Mark this as closed and resolved
